DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS in the; contract, related as it is to all the other contracts and uiauc with reference to the other contracts, defendant could not acquiesce in it as it has done for five years, and long thereafter repudiate when sued. ■ . Aside from thin plain provisions of the statutes \ which appear to me to sustain the power of the board and the contract I think the case is .ruled for the plaintiff by Oshkosh v. Fairbanks, Morse .& Co., 8 Fed. (2) 329; N. Y. Trust Co. v. Farmers Irrigations Dist., 280 Fed. 785; State vs. dering Irrigation Dist. 192 N. W. 212; (ias Securities Co. v. Antero etc. Co., 259 Fed. 425; Omaha (las Co. v. City of Omaha, 249 Fed. 350; Village of Davenport vs. Meyer Hydro Electric Co., 193 N. W. 719; Central Power Co. vs. Central City, 282 Fed. 998; Slocum vs. North Platte, 192 Fed. 252; Rogers vs. City of Omaha, 80 Neb. 591; 107 N. W.j 214; Vicksburg vs. Vicksburg Water Co. 206 U. S. 496; Ohio & M. R. Co. vs. McCarthy, 96 U. S. 258; Wynian vs. Searle, 128 N. W. 802; 23 C. J. 1»2, Sec. 1901; U. S. vs. West Side Irrig. Co. 230 Fed. 284; 246 Fed. 212; U. S. vs. Rimishorn Ditch Co., 254 Fed. 842. There should be a judgment in favor of the United States and against the defendant for the amounts due under the contract, and interest as stipulated, and costs.

REPORT OF SECRETARY IX THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITKD STATUS FOR THE DISTRICT OF NEBRASKA CHADROX DIVISION Alice Slattery, et al, -| Complainants, I vs - }• ' Equity No. 49 Clarence H. Dout, et al Defendants, i • ■ '• MEMORAXDIM DISMISSING FOR WAST OF JU tlSDICTIOX BY THE COURT, Woodrough, District Judge. The plaintiffs seek to present a controversy wholly I etween citizens of this state concerning rights to use water for Irrigation and domestic purposes out of a little stream referred to as a rivulk Trespasses by force are allied, and former adjudications betwe. it 'predecessors m interest, and it is said some claims have l, een set u r wrongfully by defendants to the effect that the state. of Nebraska ha. I Riven a right to use the water. Plaintiffs claim tl.eir suit arises under the laws of the United States because their lands where the -waters flow were Patented under the homestead laws and so their right to the water rests in federal law and. that their suit arises under t lie constitution because they are threatened with deprivation of property wlthont due procpss. . - . - Neither ground is tenable. Non-navigable streams within the several states are subject to state and not federal srvereigntv and the states may. and usually do. resulate riparian uses of. ,| )( . W, er By conveying to settlers the lands where the streams rise and flow the federal government surrendered its control of the water so that controversies arising between individuals over riparian uses cannot be said to arise under federal laws. Plaintiffs do not set cut any statute of the State of Nebraska which e.ther in its terms or in its operation, is violatlve of t[ lfi due process clause of the federal constitution. . • i»o<<.ss. ther T J ere I" T R r" nd ° f federa ' j " ris<Ii(ltio^ <■>"<' the bill should therefore, he dismissed. Sept. 23. 1920.

DEPARTMENT. OF PUBLIC WORKS Mr. R. H. Willis, Chief ot the Bureau at Irrigation, Bridneport, Nebraska. Dear Mr. Willis: Reference is made to a copy ot your letter dated June 1, 1929, to Mr. George W. Ayers, Assistant Attorney General, in which you Te - <iuest an opinion relative to your jurisdiction and duties pertaining to the distribution o( water for the purpose of irrigation along the North Platte River between the Wyoming-Nebraska line and Broad - water, Nebraska, and in particular whether the state or Federal government has' jurisidiction to administer the distribution, in Ne - braska, of storage water, under what are known as Warren Act con - tracts, entered into between appropriators and the Secretary ot the Interior. In my opinion the State of Nebraska, through its duly constituted officers, has exclusive jurisdiction to control and supervise the use of water from the North Platte River for irrigation purposes, and that the Federal government has no rights to the water of the stream for such purposes except such rights as are obtained in 'accordance with the laws of the state. As far as the right to use water 1 and police non - navigable streams within the state of Nebraska are concerned, the .federal government has no greater right than an individual. When Nebraska was authorized to frame a constitution and was admitted to the Union it obtained exclusive jurisidiction over its waters subject only to the right of the Federal government to regulate navigable streams for the purposes of navigation. Kansas v. Colorado (20G U. S.) 51 L. Ed. 957. U. S. V. Kanson, 1G7 Fed. 881, p. 884. Klnney on Irrigation, Second Ed. 813, p. 15. Kirk Irrigation Dist. v. Conway, 94 Neb. 205. Both the Reclamation Act, approved June 7, 1902, 32 Stat. 388, and the Warren Act, approved February 21, 1911, ; 36 Stat. (925) recognize the exclusive jurisidiction of the state to grant or deny appropriations of water for Irrigation purposes within the boundaries of the state. Section 8 of the Reclamation Act provides: "That nothing in this act shall be construed as affecting or in - tended to affect or to in any way interfere with the laws of any state or territory relating to the control, appropriation, use, or distribution of water used in irrigation, or any vested right acquired thereunder."

REPORT OP SECRETARY Section 8478. Compiled Statutes of Nebraska for 1922 authorizes the United States in conformity with the laws of the S ate o f Ne braska to appropriate, develop and store any unappropriated water and to re nt or sell any undeve.oped, stored or flood water to any Pe -' son w ho has Bn appropriation from the naturaI y Per The stored water may be conducted into and along any natural stream tz:z: nd taken out to suppiy an a p^^or. That ::z nee JJ!hT'7r the dIStribUti ° n ot water •« ?«°»ted in accord - ance with the rights and priority of the appropriation. Section 8430 C. S. 1922, provides how the priority and amount of appropriation shall be determined.. As amended by Chapter JS o the Laws of 1929 it also contains the following provision - t> J« ha L Pr ? Vi8i0n does not in «"»y way relieve the | Department of PubHc Works from the duty of administering storage wnich 8 C D s I"' e b XP t T ly ' m r Sed UP ° n the DePartmeDt b^S«oa 84,8, c. S. 1922, but is completely interwoven with the laws of this state pertaining to appropriations and priorities. Section 430 a

DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS water in the river, and to see that one Warren Act j contractor does not take the water which belongs to another. Taking up now the .specific points, concerning which you desire an opinion, I would advise you as follows: 1. The water superintendent should supervise the distribution of storage water tinder the law as it now stands. 2. You should determine the rights of Warren Act contractors or other parties claiming storage water, from the contracts covering such storage on file in the Department of Public Works, and required to be filed there by Section 8478, C. S. 1922. If, however, the Sec - retary of the Interior, or other party furnishing storage water to an appropriator within this state, should notify you in writing that stor - age water is being furnished for a particular appropriator or carrier of appropriations you should treat such notice as a modification of the original contract and permit the diversion of water in accordance therewith. Provided, however, sufficient storage water is in the river at the point of diversion to supply such appropriator or carrier in accordance with his or its contract; and there is also sufficient storage water in the river to satisfy all other storage contracts. If there is not Kiifficieni storage water to satisfy all Warren Act contracts and Jill contracts call for an equal right in the matter of time then you should prorate the available supply. 3. Water of the streams of this state, regardless of how it reaches the stream, should only be considered marked or storage water until the storage contracts have been supplied according! to their terms. After that any water is out of control, is free water! and belongs to the people. 4. Chapter 133 of the Session Laws or 1929, does not take away ' any essential requirement of Section 8478, C. S. 1922, prior to the amendment insofar as the duties of the Department of Public Works are .concerned with reference to its jurisdiction to supervise the dis - tribution of storage water. Under the Warren Act contract between the Secretary of the Interior and the Tri-State Land Company, whose . * successor is now the Farmers Irrigation District, entered into April 2G, 1913, the Farmers Irrigation District is only entitled to storage water as provided in Article One of said contract and the schedule ot - maximum and minimum amounts are clearly stated in said article. The provision of this contract shows that it was the intention that the storage water should supplement the natural flow, and that the stor - age water is not to be delivered in addition to the appropriation under the state law. That is, if there should be 713 cubic feet per second of water in the river at the' diversion works ot the Farmers Irrigation District on June 30th, of any year, then the district would not be

Elevation of nails is T.55 feet above zero of gage. ■ i DISTANCE FROM PATHFINDER:— 422 miles. ■ South Platte ltiver at . Julesbarg, Colorado LOCATION:— -South of Julesburg and approximately two miles from the Nebraska-Colorado Une. The river is divided into four chan - nels, numbered one, two, three and four, beginning with the south channel. Channels one and two are the principal channels. Channels three and four, carry no water of consequence except during the flood periods. During floods the four channels become one channel. RECORDS AVAILABLE:— April 1902 to November 14, 1906; May 12, 1908 to September 30, 1914; January 1st, 1923 to September 30, 1930. j GAGES: — All channels are provided with chain gages on the down stream side of the bridge. ChanneU one and two are provided with staff gages. Channel No. One has a vertical staff and Channel No. Two a sloping staff. Nebraska maintains a Stevens Continuous Automatic i ■ ■ , .
